articles.title: The Pomodoro
paragraphs: The Pomodoro Techique is a time management method developed by Francesco Cirillo in the late 1980s. It uses a kitchen timer to break work into intervals, typically 25 minutes in length, separated by short breaks. Each interval is known as pomodoro, from the Italian word for tomato, after the tomato-shaped kitchen timer that Cirillo used while he was a university student. A goal of this technique is to reduce the effect of internal and external interruptions of focus and flow.

options: A word used for kitchen clock
The name of the founder of this technique
Because it means 25 minutes in Italian
The Founder of this technique liked this word a lot, as it was also popular among Italians at the time
Because founder of this technique used tomato-shaped clock during his university years, inspired by this, he put this name to the technique
Italians insisted him to put this name, as it was symbol of time in Italy at the time

articles.title: A Short Walk
paragraphs: Walking the dusty road, the traveler found a lone tree giving shade. He rested, ate bread, and watched a child fly a bright kite.
The breeze carried the scent of baked bread and distant markets, and for a moment everything felt ordinary and full of small meaning.

articles.title: City Lights
paragraphs: At night the city hums with lights and voices. Cafes glow, and people move like rivers.
On the corner, someone plays a melody on an old guitar; the sound threads through the alleys and becomes a small shared memory.
